./.title: README
./.body:
ENVITED Ecosystem Specifications (EVES)
Welcome to the ENVITED Ecosystem Specifications (EVES) repository!
This repository contains the official specifications for the ENVITED-X Data Space, maintained by the Automotive Solution Center for Simulation e.V. (ASCS).
These specifications define and document implementation decisions, processes, and standards for the ecosystem.
Repository Structure
The repository is organized into the following structure:
ðŸ“ drafts/-> Contains EVES in the Draft stage. Each proposal is under active discussion and subject to change.
ðŸ“ final/-> Contains EVES that have been approved and finalized. These are the official and adopted specifications.
ðŸ“ resources/-> Contains additional files such as schemas, templates, and reference implementations related to specific EVES.
ðŸ“„ README.md-> This document, providing an overview of the repository.
Folder Structure Details
Drafts Folder
ðŸ“ drafts/

ðŸ“ EVES-001/  

ðŸ“„ EVES-001.md (Specification in Draft stage)  
ðŸ“„ schema.json (Optional: Schema or related resources for the EVES)  


ðŸ“ EVES-002/

ðŸ“„ EVES-002.md  
ðŸ“„ diagram.png (Optional: Diagrams or illustrations for the EVES)  



Final Folder
ðŸ“ final/

ðŸ“ EVES-001/

ðŸ“„ EVES-001.md (Finalized specification)  
ðŸ“„ reference_implementation.zip (Optional: Associated reference implementation)  


ðŸ“ EVES-002/  

ðŸ“„ EVES-002.md  
ðŸ“„ schema.json  



Resources Folder
ðŸ“ resources/

ðŸ“„ eves-template.md (Template for creating a new EVES)  
ðŸ“„ style-guide.md (Guidelines for writing EVES documents)  
ðŸ“„ schemas/  
ðŸ“„ example_schema.json (Example schema for use in EVES)  



How to Use This Repository

Explore Specifications:  

Navigate to final/ to view adopted specifications.  
Check drafts/ for work in progress and contribute to discussions.


Propose a New EVES:  

Use the template in resources/eves-template.md to draft your proposal.  
Follow the guidelines and contribution rules to submit your EVES as a pull request.
Follow the style guidelines.


Contribute to Drafts:  

Participate in discussions on draft EVES by commenting on GitHub issues or pull requests.


Access Additional Resources:  

Use schemas, templates, and guides in the resources/ folder to support your contributions.



Legend

ðŸ“ folderName: A folder in the repository.  
ðŸ“„ fileName: A file in the repository.  
-> Description: Description of the folder or file.  
(Optional): The file or folder is not mandatory and may be added as needed.


For more details on the EVES process, refer to EVES-001.Questions? Open an issue or join the discussion on GitHub!

drafts/EVES-001/eves-001.html.title: EVES-001
drafts/EVES-001/eves-001.html.body:
Abstract
This specification establishes the formal process for creating, editing, and approving ENVITED Ecosystem Specifications (EVES).
These specifications standardize and document implementation decisions for the ENVITED-X Data Space, promoting transparency, collaboration, and technical consistency within the ecosystem of the Automotive Solution Center for Simulation e.V. (ASCS).
Motivation
A standardized process for EVES ensures clarity, inclusivity, and accountability in the evolution of the ENVITED ecosystem. By defining roles, responsibilities, and lifecycle stages, this process aligns with best practices from similar initiatives, such as Chain Agnostic Improvement Proposals (CAIPs).
Specification
1. EVES Lifecycle
The EVES lifecycle consists of the following stages:

Draft:

The EVES is created and submitted as a pull request to the GitHub repository.
Initial feedback is gathered informally.


Review:

EVES Editors ensure compliance with format and process guidelines.
The community provides input via GitHub discussions.


Candidate:

The EVES achieves community consensus.
A reference implementation must be created to demonstrate feasibility and validate the proposal.


Final:

The EVES undergoes final review by designated Approvers.
Upon approval, the EVES is merged and marked as Final.


Deferred/Rejected:

Proposals not meeting the required criteria or consensus may be deferred for future consideration or rejected.



2. EVES Numbering
EVES documents follow sequential numbering, starting from EVES-001, EVES-002, and so forth. This ensures easy identification and reference.
3. EVES Types
EVES documents can fall into one of the following types:

Standards:

Defines technical specifications or protocols that should be adopted by the ecosystem.
Examples: data formats, communication protocols, APIs.


Informational:

Provides general guidelines, explanations, or context for ecosystem participants.
Examples: best practices, usage recommendations.


Process:

Outlines procedural or governance rules that apply to the ENVITED community.
Examples: this EVES-001, editorial governance rules.



Each EVES type must be specified in the document header under the "Type" field.
4. Roles and Responsibilities
Author

Any individual or group proposing an EVES.
Responsible for drafting, gathering feedback, and revising the proposal.

Community

All stakeholders who discuss, review, and provide input on EVES.

EVES Editors

Members of the ENVITED Research Cluster within ASCS.
Oversee formatting, process adherence, and editorial mediation.
Governed by the rules outlined here.

Approvers

A designated body within ASCS ENVITED community responsible for final evaluation and adoption.

5. Reference Implementation
To proceed from Candidate to Final, a reference implementation must:

Validate the proposalâ€™s feasibility,
Serve as a practical example for adoption,
Be submitted alongside the EVES documentation.

6. Format
All EVES documents must adhere to the following structure:

Title: A descriptive and concise title.
Abstract: A summary of the proposal.
Motivation: The problem statement or justification for the proposal.
Specification: Detailed technical and procedural content.
Rationale: Explanation of the approach and alternatives considered.
Backwards Compatibility: Analysis of how the proposal interacts with existing systems.
Implementation: Guidelines or requirements for practical execution.
References: Links to related documents or discussions.

7. Process Flow

Submission:

Authors submit a pull request to the EVES GitHub repository.


Editorial Review:

EVES Editors review format and compliance with guidelines.


Community Review:

Open discussions and feedback via GitHub and other forums.


Candidate Stage:

Achieve community consensus and provide a reference implementation.


Approval:

Approvers review and mark the EVES as Final.



8. Governance
The process emphasizes openness, inclusivity, and accountability. Discussions, decisions, and documentation are publicly accessible on the EVES GitHub repository. Governance rules for EVES Editors are defined here.
Backwards Compatibility
This process introduces new standards and does not conflict with prior procedures, as it establishes a foundational framework.
References

Chain Agnostic Improvement Proposals (CAIPs)
OpenMSL Governance Rules

Implementation
The initial implementation of EVES-001 involves:

Setting up the GitHub repository here.
Establishing an editorial board from the ENVITED Research Cluster.
Publishing this document as EVES-001.
